item.title: Data Encapsulation and its Importance in RSPS Programming
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Looks good, gets the point across. Try writing better examples though, its hard to see what you’re saying in them.

Instead of using those little snippets that don’t really appear to work, try writing a class on a skill that would be easy to show examples of this in, like fishing or prayer. Create like a fish enumeration or object (put these objects inside an array), that would be a good example.

CoonHunter:

What is pathetic is I’ve been doing Java for over 3 years and I just started doing things like this for my chatroom. Wonder why it took me so long. Great read though.

Because you’ve been around here too long coony <3

Read full topic

item.title: Data Encapsulation and its Importance in RSPS Programming
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:23, topic:507683”]Tried this,

[Player]
-[Bank]
–[Item[]]
-[Inventory]
–[Item[]]
-[Client]
–[PacketHandler]
—[packets…]
-[Position]
-[Interface]
…

[Shop]
-[Item[]]

[Item]
-[itemID]
-[Amount]
-[value…508]

gets to be a lot of classes :[/quote]
You could one Item container class to handle bank items, inventory items, and whatever else

Why would you even need this for interfaces

and even then it’s still not that many classes lol but if you still insist on the old way have fun declaring 7 asynchronous lists to handle global items

Read full topic

public void giveRares(Player player) {
player.addItem(ABYSSAL_WHIP.getID(), ABYSSAL_WHIP.getAmount());
player.addItem(MAX_GOLD.getID(), MAX_GOLD.getAmount());
}

item.title: Data Encapsulation and its Importance in RSPS Programming
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:10, topic:507683”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=625919.msg4259104#msg4259104 date=1363267276]

[CODE]private static Item ABYSSAL_WHIP = new Item(4151, 1);
private static Item MAX_GOLD = new Item(995, Integer.MAX_VALUE);

public void giveRares(Player player) {
player.addItem(ABYSSAL_WHIP);
player.addItem(MAX_GOLD);
}[/CODE]

See the problem with that is the way Java passes objects. If you don’t create a new instance of the item when it is given out, everyone will share that instance and be able to modify it.

then make it final, but yeah you’re right
[/quote]
Final doesn’t protect the encapsulated data. You HAVE to create a new instance when you use that example[/quote]
you’re right again, sorry

Read full topic
item.source: Data Encapsulation and its Importance in RSPS Programming

item.title: Data Encapsulation and its Importance in RSPS Programming
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:9, topic:507683”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=625919.msg4259041#msg4259041 date=1363247796]

[CODE]private static Item ABYSSAL_WHIP = new Item(4151, 1);
private static Item MAX_GOLD = new Item(995, Integer.MAX_VALUE);

public void giveRares(Player player) {
player.addItem(ABYSSAL_WHIP);
player.addItem(MAX_GOLD);
}[/CODE]

See the problem with that is the way Java passes objects. If you don’t create a new instance of the item when it is given out, everyone will share that instance and be able to modify it.
[/quote]
then make it final, but yeah you’re right[/quote]
Final doesn’t protect the encapsulated data. You HAVE to create a new instance when you use that example

Read full topic

private static Item MAX_GOLD = new Item(995, Integer.MAX_VALUE);

public void giveRares(Player player) {
player.addItem(ABYSSAL_WHIP);
player.addItem(MAX_GOLD);
}[/CODE]
[/quote]
See the problem with that is the way Java passes objects. If you don’t create a new instance of the item when it is given out, everyone will share that instance and be able to modify it.[/quote]
then make it final, but yeah you’re right
